dataset.title: Stem height and diameter for Long Term Forest Reserve Plots in CPCRW

para.literalLayout: While metadata will be freely available to those requesting it, the data manager will assure that any restrictions on access to data sets in the database will be enforced. Data will not be released without proper permission first being obtained from the investigator who generated the data.

Researchers should receive adequate acknowledgment for the use of their data by others and should be provided with copies of publications using their data. Users of data from the data base must be aware that data is not to be sold or redistributed.

It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists. Thus, the Data User will properly cite the Data Set in any publications or in the metadata of any derived data products that were produced using the Data Set.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Upland, north-facing slope. The black spruce-ericaceous (heath) shrub vegetation covering the slope has been burned (non-contiguous) in at least two patches. The understory is almost exclusively deep and continuous Sphagnum and feather moss. Ester silt loam soils overlie permafrost at shallow depths.
Upland, stream valley floor. Includes a 500 m reach of Caribou Creek
Upland south-facing slope of birch and aspen in the 70-80 year age class.
High elevation coniferous forest/tall shrub community at tree line. Transitional site between open spruce forest and tall shrub heath and alpine heath.

para.literalLayout: This study was set up to allow for initial collection of baseline data on all of the plots, as well as for long-term monitoring of each plot. To date (9/94), all Subsections of all Corners of Plots B,C & D have all been sampled for the following baseline information. Within each Subsection the location of each woody stem greater than 1.3 m height was mapped, and species, dbh, and height measured. Notes were also made as to the general condition of trees. Taxonomy followed Viereck & Little (1972) for shrubs and tree species. Periodic reobservation of height, dbh, and tree condition are to be taken at intervals as close to five years as is feasible. All data including the location of trees is verified in the field, and any necessary corrections noted. Trees that were previously accorded the status of sapling but which have grown to the minimum 1.3 m during subsequent observation are noted, measured and added to the database with a new tree number. To date, remeasure of selected Subsections has been made in Plots B, C & D. A status list of Plots is attached (see Attachment #8). Data collection, mapping and data entry were completed by teams of volunteers (a total of approximately 175 individuals to date). Volunteer teams were under the instruction and supervision of the watershed technical coordinator. Volunteers came in under the EarthWatch research program and the US Forest Service volunteer program. During the 1989 field season an intern program was initiated and three interns worked in conjunction with camp staff and volunteers to collect and enter data. The team coordinators were Brigitta Jaeger, 1987 field season; Lori Larsen, 1988; Lisa Reeber, 1989; Bill Wood, 1990 & 93, and Marya Roddis, 1994.
